title: Linux Commands Documentation
excerpt: Linux is one of the most secure, customizable, stable and reliable operating systems, making it the go-to option for DevOps engineers. As it is open-s...
content:
# Basic Linux Commands Documentation

Linux is one of the most secure, customizable, stable and reliable operating systems, making it the go-to option for DevOps engineers. As it is open-source, it is extremely customizable and is powered by contributions from developers around the world. Hence, it is imperative for any aspiring DevOps engineers to have the basic Linux commands at their fingertips.

---

## File and Directory Management

| Command | Description |
|--------|-------------|
| `pwd`  | Print current directory path. |
| `ls`   | List directory contents. |
| `cd`   | Change directory. |
| `mkdir`| Create a new directory. |
| `rm`   | Remove files or directories. |
| `cp`   | Copy files and directories. |
| `mv`   | Move or rename files and directories. |
| `touch`| Create a new empty file. |
| `find` | Search for files and directories. |

---

## File Viewing and Editing

| Command | Description |
|--------|-------------|
| `cat`   | Display contents of a file. |
| `nano`  | Edit files using a terminal-based editor. |
| `head`  | Display the beginning of a file. |
| `tail`  | Display the end of a file. |
| `echo`  | Display a line of text. |
| `wc`    | Count lines, words, and characters in a file. |

---

## Search and Filtering

| Command | Description |
|--------|-------------|
| `grep` | Search text using patterns. |

---

## Permissions and Ownership

| Command | Description |
|--------|-------------|
| `chmod` | Change file permissions. |
| `chown` | Change file ownership. |

---

## System Information and Monitoring

| Command | Description |
|--------|-------------|
| `df`     | Show disk space usage. |
| `du`     | Estimate file space usage. |
| `date`   | Display or set system date and time. |
| `whoami` | Display the current logged-in user. |
| `ps`     | Display currently running processes. |
| `top`    | Real-time view of system processes. |

---

## Process and Job Management

| Command | Description |
|--------|-------------|
| `kill`  | Terminate a process by PID. |
| `sleep` | Pause for a specified time. |

---

## Networking

| Command | Description |
|--------|-------------|
| `ping` | Send ICMP echo requests to network hosts. |
| `wget` | Download files from the internet. |
| `scp`  | Securely copy files between systems. |

---

## Help and Documentation

| Command | Description |
|--------|-------------|
| `man` | Display manual pages for commands. |

Linux is one of the most secure, customizable, stable and reliable operating systems, making it the go-to option for DevOps engineers. ## Help and Documentation

| `man` | Display manual pages for commands. |

excerpt: Next.js 15 introduces groundbreaking features that revolutionize the way we build React applications. This comprehensive guide will walk you through t...
content:
# Getting Started with Next.js 15 and TypeScript ## Introduction Next.js 15 introduces groundbreaking features that revolutionize the way we build React applications. This comprehensive guide will walk you through the latest improvements and how to leverage them in your projects. ## Key Features ### 1. **App Router Enhancements** The new App Router brings significant improvements to routing and layout management: - **Improved Performance**: Faster page loads and better caching - **Better SEO**: Enhanced metadata handling - **Simplified Layouts**: Easier nested layouts and templates ### 2. **Server Components** Server Components are now the default, offering: - **Reduced Bundle Size**: Less JavaScript sent to the client - **Better Performance**: Faster initial page loads - **Enhanced Security**: Sensitive data stays on the server ## Installation To get started with Next.js 15, run the following command: ```bash npx create-next-app@latest my-app --typescript --tailwind --app ``` ## Project Structure Your Next.js 15 project will have this structure: ``` my-app/ ├── app/ │ ├── layout.tsx │ ├── page.tsx │ └── globals.css ├── components/ ├── lib/ ├── public/ └── package.json ``` ## Configuration ### TypeScript Configuration Update your `tsconfig.json` to include the latest features: ```json { "compilerOptions": { "target": "ES2020", "lib": ["dom", "dom.iterable", "es6"], "allowJs": true, "skipLibCheck": true, "strict": true, "forceConsistentCasingInFileNames": true, "noEmit": true, "esModuleInterop": true, "module": "esnext", "moduleResolution": "bundler", "resolveJsonModule": true, "isolatedModules": true, "jsx": "preserve", "incremental": true, "plugins": [ { "name": "next" } ] } } ``` ## Best Practices ### 1. **Component Organization** - Keep components in the `components/` directory - Use descriptive file names - Group related components together ### 2. **Data Fetching** - Use Server Components for data fetching when possible - Implement proper error boundaries - Cache data appropriately ### 3. **Performance Optimization** - Use `next/image` for optimized images - Implement proper loading states - Leverage React Suspense for better UX ## Common Patterns ### Layout Pattern ```tsx // app/layout.tsx export default function RootLayout({ children, }: { children: React.ReactNode }) { return (
Navigation
{children}
Footer
) } ``` ### Page Pattern ```tsx // app/page.tsx export default async function HomePage() { const data = await fetchData() return (

Welcome to Next.js 15

This is a server component

{data.map(item => (
{item.name}
))}
) } ``` ## Advanced Features ### 1. **Parallel Routes** Enable multiple pages to be rendered simultaneously: ```tsx // app/@analytics/page.tsx export default function AnalyticsPage() { return
Analytics Dashboard
} // app/@team/page.tsx export default function TeamPage() { return
Team Management
} ``` ### 2. **Intercepting Routes** Create modal-like experiences: ```tsx // app/@modal/(.)login/page.tsx export default function LoginModal() { return (

Login

...
) } ``` ## Deployment ### Vercel Deployment 1. Push your code to GitHub 2. Connect your repository to Vercel 3. Deploy automatically on every push ### Environment Variables Set up your environment variables: ```env # .env.local DATABASE_URL=your_database_url NEXT_PUBLIC_API_URL=your_api_url ``` ## Troubleshooting ### Common Issues 1. **Build Errors** - Check TypeScript configuration - Verify all imports are correct - Ensure proper file extensions 2. **Runtime Errors** - Check browser console for errors - Verify API endpoints - Check environment variables 3. **Performance Issues** - Use React DevTools Profiler - Check bundle analyzer - Optimize images and assets ## Resources ### Official Documentation - [Next.js Documentation](https://nextjs.org/docs) - [React Documentation](https://react.dev) - [TypeScript Handbook](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs) ### Community Resources - [Next.js GitHub](https://github.com/vercel/next.js) - [React GitHub](https://github.com/facebook/react) - [Stack Overflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/next.js) ## Conclusion Next.js 15 represents a significant leap forward in React development. With its improved performance, better developer experience, and enhanced features, it's the perfect choice for building modern web applications. Remember to: - Stay updated with the latest releases - Follow best practices - Contribute to the community - Keep learning and experimenting Happy coding! 🚀 --- *This article was written for the Developers Club blog. For more content like this, visit our [blog](https://devclub.iiitdm.ac.in/blog).*
